(WLOX/Gray News) - A Mississippi city is mourning the death of its oldest living resident, a World War II veteran who died hours before his 105th birthday. Willie James Smith Sr. died Monday evening, missing his 105th birthday by a few hours. The WWII veteran was the city of Moss Point’s oldest living resident. J.B. Carter, Smith’s 86-year-old nephew, sat with a heavy heart in his home Tuesday, as he mourned his uncle, who was known as “Daddy Willie.” “All those memories just welled up in me,” Carter told WLOX. Carter says Smith loved the Lord and was his role model for as long as he can remember. “He was blessed to have a full life. All he needed to do was work and go to church,” he said. “He had a chance to see his children grow up and his grandchildren, even his great-grandchildren.” Carter also remembers Smith as a WWII veteran, one of the oldest in Jackson County. He enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1941 and was honorably discharged in 1945. “If you started talking to him about the military, he’d go all day,” Carter said. “He told you about the places he had gone to and what he did in the military.” Moss Point Mayor Billy Knight knew Smith personally and says he should be remembered for the sacrifices he made in war so that we might be free. “He’s one of a kind,” Knight said. “He cared about this country. He’s a patriot. He passed all that and instilled that to us in different ways.” He describes Smith as a man born with a purpose to help others. “If you know what your passion is, it’s probably your purpose. Then, you need to work to carry out that purpose because it really does give you something to get up for in the morning when you have that passion about something,” he said. Moss Point’s flags were lowered to half staff to honor Smith. Smith was honored by the Hattiesburg African American Museum for his service during the war last October. At that time, he said faith is what got him through a long life. Copyright 2024 WLOX via Gray Media Group, Inc. All rights reserved.'}]

'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'HIRAM, Ga. (WSB) - A Georgia mother says she shipped her 15-year-old son’s ashes from a UPS store to a family member, but the package never made it. Mother Tangenika Lee says she feels like she’s lost her 15-year-old son, Deontray, all over again after his death from a fentanyl overdose in 2020. His remains are now unaccounted for after she tried shipping them to her sister, who was making a custom cremation urn. “If you ask me, it’s just like a repeating nightmare,” Lee said. “I cremated him because I had not seen him in seven whole years. So, I cremated him, so that he could be right here with me, and we could travel together and do things together – and he ain’t here.” Lee says she shipped Deontray’s boxed ashes along with some gifts from a UPS store in Hiram, Georgia, to her sister’s address in Connecticut in early January. The package was supposed to arrive by Jan. 10. Weeks passed, but the package was never delivered. Lee called police about the missing package and went back to the UPS store to ask if they knew what happened to it. “I went inside of the store and pulled cameras from January the 8th, and they came back out to tell me that that package actually had left their facility, and it was nothing that they could do about it,” Lee said. She says UPS sent her a $135 check as compensation. She’s refusing to cash it. “I just lost it. I started crying,” Lee said. “He ain’t here. He not here. I don’t know where he at.” Lee says the store manager told her the package was last tracked to a UPS distribution center in Connecticut. She’s now planning to go there to look for her son. Lee says she told store employees that her son’s ashes were in the package. However, UPS said in a statement it does not accept shipments of human remains, and the package’s contents were declared by the customer as “clothes.” “Unfortunately, the package was lost,” read the statement in part. “We extend our deepest sympathy to the family and our heartfelt thoughts are with them during this time.” Copyright 2024 WSB via CNN Newsource. All rights reserved.'}]

human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'TRUMANN, Ark. (KAIT) - After days of K8 News investigating allegations of abuse in a Trumann classroom, school officials confirm a teacher has been placed on administrative leave. However, the police report tells a different story. On Wednesday, Jan. 31, the Trumann School District confirmed Hannah Jones was placed on administrative leave, citing an investigation surrounding an alleged Jan. 24 incident with students. K8 News began inquiries on Friday, Jan. 26, after receiving numerous emails and Facebook messages regarding the teacher’s alleged conduct in the classroom. Attorney Rebecca Worsham, who represents the school district, said at the time there was no evidence to the allegations. A few days later, on Jan. 31, Worsham confirmed that “based on new information, the district has placed the teacher on administrative leave and is conducting a further investigation into this matter.” K8 News also reached out to Trumann police numerous times. Chief Jonathan Redman told one of our producers on Tuesday, Jan. 30, that it was an “active investigation” and he could not release the report. On Thursday, Feb. 1, after yet another phone call to Redman, he finally sent the initial incident report to K8 News. According to the report, 52-year-old Lou Ella Clover of Trumann stated that on Jan. 25, Jones “set a time for one minute and allowed the other children in the class to strike her grandson.” Clover claimed multiple parents reported the incident to her and that when she approached the school administration about the incident, “she felt that [they] were not being honest with her.” On Jan. 30, Sergeant Johnny Johnson and Superintendent Brandie Williams viewed a classroom video recorded from 3 to 3:30 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 24. Johnson stated he observed Jones sitting at her desk while “nearly all of the students participated in roughhousing with each other, including the alleged victim.” He also reported viewing the alleged victim running in the classroom. “At other times in the video, students, including the alleged victim, kicked and punched at each other in a playful manner,” Johnson said. “No genuine aggression was observed.” He noted that Jones could be heard telling the students to “calm down and return to their seats.” “I did not observe, at any time during the video, the teacher setting a timer and allowing any of the other students to strike the alleged victim,” Johnson stated in his report. “I was advised that the timer in question is used for bathroom breaks.” He also said the alleged victim did not seem to be in “any state of distress.” The Trumann Police Department submitted a report to the Child Abuse Hotline. As of Friday, Feb. 9, Worsham confirmed to K8 News that Jones is still on leave as the investigation is ongoing. Copyright 2024 KAIT. All rights reserved.'}]
